item.title: building a digital garden with Logseq and Hugo
item.description: We, as people, are social animals. We live together, we work together, we relax together, but what about learning together? In these days of global pandemics and, be honest, living inside our digital tools we have slowly gone back to being not-very-social. Digital gardens are one way to overcome this modern ill: Learning and building/creating in such a way that it is easy for others to see and/or comment on what you do and learn.

javascript
item.description: Logseq plugins are developed in Javascript and that is the reason I have been reading more on how to use it well. Here you will find mostly notes related to plugin development.

item.title: logseq
item.description: Note: This place is currently a placeholder, hugo gets upset if links are missing. In the future this page will be a collection of useful links to learn how to more effectively use Logseq. Related: javascript for plugins, datalog for queries.

item.title: pkm
item.description: Personal knowledge management (PKM) is a process of collecting information that a person uses to gather, classify, store, search, retrieve and share knowledge in their daily activities (Grundspenkis 2007) and the way in which these processes support work activities (Wright 2005). It is a response to the idea that knowledge workers need to be responsible for their own growth and learning (Smedley 2009). It is a bottom-up approach to knowledge management (KM) (Pollard 2008).

item.title: query views
item.description: Note: This place is currently a placeholder, hugo gets upset if links are missing. Queries are build in a language called datalog, the presentation is done using Hiccup. Mixed in is Clojure, of which I know none. Debugging Usually I add one of these to view raw data from a query before I add custom hiccup view :view (fn [result] (for [r result] [:pre (pr-str r)]))

item.title: Streaming to a chromecast
item.description: My mom complained about an English only TV series on Disney+. What’s a helpful son to do? As it happens, streaming to a Chromecast is not hard, but sending subtitles to it seems to be all but impossible. So, hardcoded subs it is (Just like the nineties, how retro!). Step by step This was the easiest way to get some subtitled videos on TV:

item.title: Hiccup
item.description: Hiccup is a domain-specific language for generating HTML, used mostly in Clojure community. For every day use you need very little knowledge of Hiccup, and fortunately (most of it) is surprisingly simple. Let&rsquo;s Hiccup The most obvious thing you can use Hiccup for is to style the titles of Advanced Queries: #+BEGIN_QUERY {:title [:h3 "This is hiccup!"] :query [:find (pull ?b [*]) :where [task ?
